Simple Training/Test Set Splitting for Time Series

Source: R/rsample-initial_time_split_2.R
initial_time_split_2.Rd

initial_time_split_2() creates training and testing sets for Time Series Validation. This version differs from rsample::initial_time_split() in that it has an overlap parameter which is useful for prediction with lagged predictors.

initial_time_split_2(data, prop = 3/4, overlap = 0, ...)

Arguments

data

A data frame.
prop

The proportion of data to be retained for modeling/analysis.
overlap

A value to include an overlap between the assessment and analysis set. This is useful if lagged predictors will be used during training and testing.
...

Not currently used.

Value

An rset object that can be used with the training and testing functions to extract the data in each split.

Details

Lagged Predictors

overlap enables the test data to overlap with the training data, which is useful for predictions needing access to prior history such as when using lagged predictors.

Examples

library(recipes)
#> Loading required package: dplyr
#> 
#> Attaching package: ‘dplyr’
#> The following objects are masked from ‘package:stats’:
#> 
#>     filter, lag
#> The following objects are masked from ‘package:base’:
#> 
#>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union
#> 
#> Attaching package: ‘recipes’
#> The following object is masked from ‘package:stats’:
#> 
#>     step
library(rsample)
#> Loading required package: tidyr
#> Registered S3 methods overwritten by 'rsample':
#>   method               from  
#>   print.rolling_origin timetk
#>   print.rsplit         timetk
library(timetk)
library(tidyverse)
#> ── Attaching packages ─────────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse 1.3.0 ──
#> ✓ ggplot2 3.3.0     ✓ purrr   0.3.3
#> ✓ tibble  2.1.3     ✓ stringr 1.4.0
#> ✓ readr   1.3.1     ✓ forcats 0.5.0
#> ── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
#> x dplyr::filter()  masks stats::filter()
#> x stringr::fixed() masks recipes::fixed()
#> x dplyr::lag()     masks stats::lag()

# 5-years of monthly data
drinks_subset <- drinks %>%
    tail(5*12) %>%
    rename(sales = S4248SM144NCEN) %>%
    as_tibble()

# Time series split with 12 period overlap
drinks_overlap_split <- initial_time_split_2(
    drinks_subset,
    prop    = 4 / 5,
    overlap = 12
)

# Extract train and test sets
train_data <- training(drinks_overlap_split)
test_data  <- testing(drinks_overlap_split)

# Note 12 period overlap
train_data %>% tail(12)
#> # A tibble: 12 x 2
#>    date       sales
#>    <date>     <dbl>
#>  1 2015-10-01 11983
#>  2 2015-11-01 11506
#>  3 2015-12-01 14183
#>  4 2016-01-01  8650
#>  5 2016-02-01 10323
#>  6 2016-03-01 12110
#>  7 2016-04-01 11424
#>  8 2016-05-01 12243
#>  9 2016-06-01 13686
#> 10 2016-07-01 10956
#> 11 2016-08-01 12706
#> 12 2016-09-01 12279
test_data
#> # A tibble: 24 x 2
#>    date       sales
#>    <date>     <dbl>
#>  1 2015-10-01 11983
#>  2 2015-11-01 11506
#>  3 2015-12-01 14183
#>  4 2016-01-01  8650
#>  5 2016-02-01 10323
#>  6 2016-03-01 12110
#>  7 2016-04-01 11424
#>  8 2016-05-01 12243
#>  9 2016-06-01 13686
#> 10 2016-07-01 10956
#> # … with 14 more rows

# Make recipe
rec_lag <- recipe(sales ~ ., training(drinks_overlap_split)) %>%
    step_lag(sales, lag = 12) %>%
    step_naomit(all_predictors())

# Apply recipe to test data - Correctly applies the lag
bake(prep(rec_lag), testing(drinks_overlap_split))
#> # A tibble: 12 x 3
#>    date       sales lag_12_sales
#>    <date>     <dbl>        <dbl>
#>  1 2016-10-01 11914        11983
#>  2 2016-11-01 13025        11506
#>  3 2016-12-01 14431        14183
#>  4 2017-01-01  9049         8650
#>  5 2017-02-01 10458        10323
#>  6 2017-03-01 12489        12110
#>  7 2017-04-01 11499        11424
#>  8 2017-05-01 13553        12243
#>  9 2017-06-01 14740        13686
#> 10 2017-07-01 11424        10956
#> 11 2017-08-01 13412        12706
#> 12 2017-09-01 11917        12279
